The crew aboard the RV Hugh R. Sharp gets to work cleaning up after a scallop dredge.

Beachgoers sometimes find "mermaid's purses". The "purse" is the egg case of a skate or a shark.

Captured sharks are brought on board so that scientists can collect data.

Large sharks are brought up to the boat rail in a cradle.

A scientist weighs a medium-sized shark in a cradle before returning it to the ocean.

Tiger shark teeth are different from the teeth of most sharks.

Male sharks have claspers (left). Female sharks do not.

The back of sharks' eyeballs have a reflective layer of tissue called a tapetum.

A sea scallop's eyes are the black dots that line the edges of its shells

The largest scallops are shucked so their meat weights can be analyzed later in the lab.

After being measured and weighed, these sea scallops are returned to the ocean.

This "sea mouse" is not a mouse, but a marine polychaete worm.

A scientist distributes the catch to others who will sort it into buckets.

Part of surveying sea scallop populations involves skimming the ocean floor with a dredge to collect samples.

Scientists deploy a device called the HabCam into the ocean to take pictures of habitat on the ocean floor.

Both this pipefish and this waterstrider live in the sargassum off the coast of Florida.

The sargassum fish is a weak swimmer that spends its life clinging to the floating seaweed.

The color of this filefish makes it difficult to find in the sargassum.

This sargassum sample may contain plankton, worms, small fish, and small crabs.

Because the Neuston net is pulled along the ocean's surface, it often picks up sargassum.

The Neuston net is used to collect small organisms that live on the ocean's surface.
Did You Know? Tweets from Sea
Sargassum can clump together to form vast mats that float on the surface of the ocean.
Did You Know? Tweets from Sea
Sargassum is a free-floating seaweed that provides refuge for many small creatures.

While at sea, everyone working on a NOAA research ship pitches in to help clean the deck.
Did You Know? Tweets from Sea
This fish, the polka dot batfish, is a bottom-dwelling species that uses its stubby fins to "walk" along the seafloor.

A chevron trap is baited, mounted with cameras, and lowered near to catch fish for 90 minutes.

Scientists sample reef fish using a chevron trap, a fish trap named for its chevron shape.
Did You Know? Tweets from Sea
Sandbar sharks have particularly large dorsal fins.
Did You Know? Tweets from Sea
A 500-micrometer sieve collects tiny organisms from the contents of a bongo net's codend.
Did You Know? Tweets from Sea
At the end of each bongo net is a container called a "codend" that lets only tiny organisms through.
Did You Know? Tweets from Sea
Scientists use a bongo net, named for its resemblance to bongo drums, to take plankton samples.

Scientists measure the elevation distance between benchmarks so they know whether the area is geologically stable.

Benchmarks are installed and stamped by hand with a hammer and letter stamps.

Scientists install a series of five benchmarks, lettered A-E, at a single tide station.

Permanent benchmarks provide reference points on land for tide gauges installed nearby.

To verify that the underwater tidal gauge is calculating water levels accurately, scientists install a tide staff that allows them to read tide levels visually.

A tide station installed in  the Gulf of Alaska measures, records, and transmits tide levels over time.

Once a launch has finished surveying its polygon, or survey area, it returns to the larger hydrographic ship.

A hammerhead's eyes are located at either end of its head, which is called a "cephalofoil."
Did You Know? Tweets from Sea
NOAA hydrographic ships carry small boats called ?survey launches? that are lowered into the water to survey shallower areas.

The trawling net is used to collect groundfish samples. This helps scientists estimate fish populations.

Scientists use a fish's ear bones, called otoliths, to tell its age by counting the rings just as one does with a tree trunk.

Lionfish are invading Southeastern U.S. coral reefs.

Stargazers have an electric organ and are able to produce electricity, known as bioelectrogenesis.

Sea spiders like this one have no lungs or other respiratory organs.

The flame box crab uses its scissor-like claws to act as a can opener. It opens hermit crabs in this way.

This is a type of bashful crab, also known as the flame box crab (Calappa flammea).

Humpback whales periodically leap out of the water. This is called breaching.

Scientists tag Kemp's Ridley sea turtles so that they can monitor their movement, age, and growth.
Did You Know? Tweets from Sea
Artificial reefs provide a sturdy structure for a wide variety of species to call home.

Scientists use an instrument called the Cam-Trawl to take photos of fish during surveys in Alaska.

Circle hooks are designed to catch a shark or fish without the hook being swallowed.

Once scientists have measured, weighed, and tagged the shark, they allow the shark to swim free.

Scientists tag an Atlantic sharpnose shark. Each time the shark is captured again, scientists will record its new location.
